Day 19 of November 2020 - Ground: Yesterday I spent the day in bed trying (and often failing) to resist the urge to hurt myself because I didn't want to live anymore. Today I woke up feeling numb and sore and drained, but Adriene's invitation to accept who/where you are today and "not who or where you were yesterday" really hit home. It's a running joke in my family the amount of times medical professionals have suggested I try yoga to cure my depression, and whilst it by no means has, it gets me out of bed most mornings and allows me to forgive myself. When Adriene invited us to complete the sentence "I choose..." I said to myself that I choose life.

Can somebody give me an advice if this 1 month challenge is okay for me if I am a beginner or should i start with some other videos ?

I've gone to quite a few teachers and I think Adriene is a fantastic beginner teacher. If you haven't done any yoga with a teacher before however I would recommend starting with her foundations yoga pose videos. You can also google yoga tips and individual poses for how to do them correctly. You want to make sure you're not improperly aligned while doing the poses. Always keep a microbend in your joints to protect them. Don't overstretch. Remember that nothing should hurt or feel uncomfortable. Listen to your body. How you move on the mat can change your neural pathways off the mat (so awesome!). You'll be totally fine doing her 1 month challenges though. If it's ever too much, just sit in child's pose and listen until you are able to control your breathing again. Then rejoin when you're ready. Child's pose is yoga. Yoga is the union of breath and body. That's what you should focus on to reap the best mental rewards. The physical rewards will come. Good luck! It's fun.

Hi Renata! There is a Prenatal Yoga For All Trimesters available in the FWFG Membership - fwfg.com and in the shop - https://do.yogawithadriene.com/, if you're interested.

In general, most women are able to continue a regular practice through month eight if they avoid twists below the neck, core activation and anything on the belly. Most will find they will know when something isn't right. Hip openers are good but go easier in third trimester. Modify core breaks with reclined cobbler's pose, modify belly stuff with child's pose or yogi's squat and modify standing twists with wide-legged forward fold. 

As always, consult your doctor/physician before starting and follow their advice. xx
